questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being struck by a car while he was crossing the street one hour ago. He did not lose consciousness. He has pain in his right arm, forehead, and pelvis. He also has an urge to urinate but has been unable to do so since the accident. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/82 mm Hg. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. There are abrasions over his scalp and face and a 1 x 3 cm area of ecchymosis above his right eye. His pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. Musculoskeletal examination shows tenderness and ecchymosis over the right distal forearm with intact pulses, sensation, and capillary refill. There is no tenderness of the cervical spine. Abdominal examination shows suprapubic tenderness. A scant amount of blood is present at the urethral meatus. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows a fracture of both ipsilateral pubic rami. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Retrograde urethrography is the first step in diagnosing suspected urethral injuries such as posterior urethral injury, which often occurs in patients with pelvic fractures due to blunt force trauma (e.g., from motor vehicle collisions). Contrast extravasation from the urethra indicates the precise location of the injury. In addition to the inability to void and blood at the urethral meatus, both seen here, findings that raise concern for posterior urethral injury include scrotal and perineal ecchymoses and a high-riding prostate on digital rectal examination.

Foley catheterization should be avoided in patients with suspected urethral injury because it may worsen the condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous pyelography can be used in the evaluation of kidney injuries. This patient does not have features suggesting a kidney injury, such as significant blood loss, hemodynamic instability, ipsilateral pain, or hematoma. Furthermore, in recent years, IV pyelography has been largely replaced by contrast-enhanced CT for diagnosing kidney injuries.

C) INCORRECT:

Retrograde cystography is used to assess for bladder rupture in patients with a pelvic fracture or gross hematuria due to trauma. However, before performing cystography, urethral injury should be ruled out with a different diagnostic approach.

D) INCORRECT:

Foley catheterization is commonly used in patients with urinary retention. However, urethral catheterization should be avoided in suspected urethral injury as it may worsen the condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Retroperitoneal ultrasound can be used to evaluate retroperitoneal structures, including the kidneys. However, this patient does not have signs of a kidney injury, such as significant blood loss, hemodynamic instability, ipsilateral pain, or hematoma.
questions.hint: Blood at the urethral meatus and features of urinary retention (inability to void, suprapubic pain) in the setting of a pelvic fracture suggest posterior urethral injury.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after losing control of his bicycle and colliding with a parked car. He was thrown over the handlebars and hit the ground. He reports that he was wearing a helmet and that he did not lose consciousness. He has mild pain in his legs and on his right side but says that he feels well otherwise. On arrival, he is alert and oriented. His pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/76 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There are a few bruises over his right chest, flank, and lower extremities. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is tenderness to palpation over the right thorax. There is no pelvic instability. The external genitalia appear normal. Complete blood count, prothrombin time, and serum concentrations of glucose, creatinine, and electrolytes are within the reference ranges. A voided urine specimen is clear. Microscopic examination of the urine shows 85 RBCs/hpf. A focused assessment with sonography for trauma shows no free intra-abdominal fluid. An x-ray of the chest shows a fracture of the 11th rib on the right side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Placement of a suprapubic catheter is indicated to relieve and prevent urinary retention. Indications of suprapubic catheter placement include urethral injuries requiring surgical repair, urethral obstruction, acute prostatitis, or prostate cancer in which transurethral catheterization is contraindicated or technically not possible. Microscopic hematuria, as seen in this patient, can be a sign of a mild urethral injury, but it would need to be confirmed before a suprapubic catheterization is considered. In addition, the patient has no signs of urinary retention such as abdominal pain or a palpable suprapubic mass.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous pyelography (IVP) is used for the evaluation of possible renal disease, detection of renal stones, or to assess potential contrast extravasation if contrast-enhanced CT images are not diagnostic. IVP was formerly a preferred imaging modality for renal trauma; however, a different test has supplanted IVP as the imaging modality of choice.

C) INCORRECT:

Exploratory laparotomy after BAT is indicated in hemodynamically unstable patients with signs of peritonitis and hemodynamically stable patients with evidence of free intra-abdominal fluid on imaging. This patient is hemodynamically stable and focused assessment with sonography for trauma is normal.

D) CORRECT:

In patients with BAT, a CT scan with contrast of the abdomen and pelvis is the imaging modality of choice for evaluating abdominal injuries, including those of the genitourinary tract. BAT is a major cause of mortality and requires a high degree of clinical suspicion, even if a patient's initial presentation does not suggest any significant intra-abdominal injury. This patient with suspected renal trauma requires a CT scan with contrast of the abdomen and pelvis to establish the diagnosis and further assess the degree of trauma.

E) INCORRECT:

Retrograde urethrocystography is used to evaluate the lower genitourinary tract and urinary bladder. It is indicated in patients with gross hematuria or blood at the urethral meatus following a pelvic fracture. This patient, however, only has microscopic hematuria and no signs of a pelvic fracture. Therefore, a retrograde urethrocystography is not indicated at this time.

F) INCORRECT:

Observation and follow-up may be appropriate in patients who are hemodynamically stable and have no signs of traumatic injury. Although mild microscopic hematuria is common following BAT and does not necessarily indicate genitourinary injury, this patient has evidence of a right rib fracture, which is concerning for a renal injury. Therefore, observation and follow-up would not be an appropriate next step.
questions.hint: The combination of a fracture of the 11th rib on the right side and microscopic hematuria in a patient with a history of blunt abdominal trauma (BAT) should raise concern for renal injury.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after he was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision where he was the unrestrained passenger. He has severe lower abdominal and pelvic pain. On arrival, he is alert and oriented. His pulse is 95/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 106/62 mm Hg. Examination shows severe tenderness to palpation over the lower abdomen and over the left anterior superior iliac spine. There is no limb length discrepancy. Application of downward pressure over the pelvis shows no springy resistance or instability. Rectal examination is unremarkable. There is no blood at the urethral meatus. Placement of a Foley catheter shows gross hematuria. A focused assessment with sonography shows no free fluid in the abdomen. An x-ray of the pelvis shows a stable fracture of the anterior pelvic ring. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous pyelography can be used to assess for renal injury. The most frequent indication for IV pyelography is as a confirmatory test if CT scanning is nondiagnostic. Renal trauma can also manifest with hematuria and should be suspected in patients with associated injuries (e.g., rib fractures) or pain and hematoma over the flank. Because renal trauma is less likely in a patient with lower abdominal pain and a pelvic fracture, evaluation of the lower urinary tract must first be conducted.

B) INCORRECT:

Cystoscopy is indicated for non-emergent cases of unexplained hematuria, but it is not indicated for traumatic hematuria and could further damage the urinary tract.

C) INCORRECT:

External fixation of the pelvis is part of the initial management for unstable pelvic fractures. However, this patient's pelvis was stable on examination and the x-ray showed a stable fracture of the anterior pelvic ring.

D) INCORRECT:

Retrograde urethrography is a first-line test to assess for traumatic urethral injury in patients with gross hematuria and associated signs of a urethral injury (e.g., blood at the urethral meatus, perineal hematoma). In patients with gross hematuria and no other signs of urethral injury (such as this patient) a single attempt at Foley catheter placement may be performed. Since the catheter was placed successfully in this patient, a urethral injury has virtually been ruled out and further evaluation should focus on more proximal parts of the genitourinary tract.

E) CORRECT:

Although this patient's FAST shows no free fluid in the abdomen, the presence of hematuria after blunt abdominal trauma is a red flag for GU injury and requires further evaluation. When GU trauma is suspected, the GU tract should be assessed, including the urethra, bladder, ureters, and kidneys. Pelvic fractures in combination with gross hematuria should raise concern for bladder injury. Retrograde cystography (or retrograde CT cystography) is the preferred diagnostic test in patients with suspected bladder rupture. Extravasation of contrast on retrograde cystography confirms the diagnosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Renal ultrasonography has poor sensitivity for renal trauma and is not indicated for traumatic genitourinary injury. Additionally, in this patient with lower abdominal pain, bladder rupture is a more likely cause of traumatic gross hematuria and therefore requires immediate investigation before assessing the kidneys.
questions.hint: Genitourinary (GU) trauma must always be ruled out in patients with traumatic pelvic fracture, especially when it involves the pubic rami. The presence of lower abdominal pain and gross hematuria further supports a GU trauma.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Four months ago, he was treated conservatively for ureteric colic. He has noticed during micturition that his urine is reddish-brown initially and then clears by the end of the stream. He has no dysuria. He has hypertension. His only medication is hydrochlorothiazide. He appears healthy and well-nourished. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 122/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
14.1 g/dL


Serum



 Glucose
88 mg/dL


 Creatinine
0.6 mg/dL


Urine



 Blood
2+


 Protein
negative


 Leukocyte esterase
negative


 Nitrite
negative


 RBCs
5–7/hpf


 WBCs
0–1/hpf


 RBC casts
none


Which of the following is the most likely origin of this patient's hematuria?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glomerular damage can manifest with gross hematuria. However, urine (and blood) from the kidneys collects in the bladder before urination, which causes the full volume of urine to be discolored by blood (total hematuria). Additionally, urine studies would show RBC casts and/or dysmorphic RBCs (due to erythrocyte packing within the nephron), as well as proteinuria in many cases.

B) INCORRECT:

Ureteric lesions (e.g., due to nephrolithiasis, malignancy, or infection) can manifest with hematuria. Urine (and blood) from the ureters collects in the bladder before urination, which causes the full volume of urine to be discolored by blood (total hematuria). This patient's urine is only bloody initially, then clears, which suggests another source of bleeding.

C) INCORRECT:

Hematuria from the renal pelvis can be caused by a variety of processes, including pyelonephritis, malignancy, or nephrolithiasis. However, urine (and blood) from the renal pelvis collects in the bladder before urination, causing the full volume of urine to be discolored by blood (total hematuria). While this patient has a history of nephrolithiasis, his urine is only bloody initially, suggesting another source of bleeding.

D) CORRECT:

Initial hematuria is suggestive of urethral bleeding. Blood from the urethra (or prostate) is voided first, then washed out by non-bloody urine from the bladder. For this reason, gross hematuria of urethral origin is only observed at the beginning of micturition.

Hematuria of urethral origin can have a wide variety of causes, such as infection (urethritis, prostatitis), neoplasm (urothelial carcinoma, urethral papilloma, BPH), anatomical variations (urethral stricture), and trauma (e.g., insertion of a Foley catheter, passage of a kidney stone). Patients with painless hematuria, particularly those > 35 years of age such as this patient, should always be thoroughly evaluated to rule out malignancy.

E) INCORRECT:

Bleeding from the bladder is either associated with hematuria that continues for the duration of micturition, or terminal hematuria, which suggests a lesion at the trigone.
questions.hint: The bladder stores urine (and sometimes blood) from the upper genitourinary tract, where the contents mix for extended periods of time.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after injuring his genital area when he fell astride his backyard fence. He was trimming a tree from the fence when he lost his balance. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows blood at the urethral meatus, perineal ecchymoses, and a scrotal hematoma. An x-ray of the pelvis shows swelling of the soft tissue but no other abnormalities. Which of the following parts of the urinary tract is most likely damaged in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The penile urethra can be damaged by a straddle injury like the one this patient has sustained. However, this structure is much less commonly injured compared to another genitourinary structure, because it is relatively mobile, protected by the corpora cavernosa, and does not lie in close proximity to the pubic symphysis.

B) INCORRECT:

The bladder is relatively protected from damage in straddle injuries because it is a pelvic organ. The anterior bladder wall can be injured in cases of pelvic fracture that cause extraperitoneal bladder rupture. Bladder injuries typically manifest with gross hematuria or an inability to urinate, lower abdominal pain, and/or distension.

C) CORRECT:

The bulbous urethra lies in close proximity to the pubic symphysis, is relatively immobile, and lacks the protection of the corpora cavernosa. As a result, it is the most commonly injured structure in men with straddle injuries or direct trauma (e.g., receiving a direct blow or kick) to the male perineum. This patient's findings of blood at the urethral meatus, perineal ecchymoses, and a scrotal hematoma are classic findings of urethral injury.

When a urethral injury is suspected, a retrograde urethrogram should be obtained before placement of a Foley catheter. If the bladder needs to be urgently drained before imaging, a suprapubic catheter can be placed.

D) INCORRECT:

The membranous urethra is a posterior urethral structure that lies within the pelvis and is therefore protected from direct injuries to the perineum, such as the straddle injury that this patient has sustained. Severe pelvic fracture (e.g., from an motor vehicle accident) is the typical mechanism of posterior urethral injury, which most commonly affects the membranous urethra. The shearing force detaches the prostate gland from its attachments, which results in a torn posterior urethra. A high-riding prostate on digital rectal examination is a pathognomonic feature of posterior urethral injury.

E) INCORRECT:

The bladder is relatively protected from damage in straddle injuries because it is a pelvic organ. Mechanisms of injury to the bladder neck include blunt abdominal injury, pelvic fracture, and iatrogenic causes (e.g., during transurethral resection of the prostate). Bladder injuries typically manifest with gross hematuria or an inability to urinate, lower abdominal pain, and/or distension.

F) INCORRECT:

The prostatic urethra is a posterior urethral structure that lies within the pelvis and is therefore protected from direct injuries to the perineum, such as the straddle injury that this patient has sustained. Severe pelvic fracture (e.g., from a motor vehicle accident) is the most common mechanism of posterior urethral injury. The shearing force detaches the prostate gland from its attachments, which results in a torn posterior urethra.
questions.hint: This man straddled an object and struck the genital area when he fell, which is known as a straddle injury. Damage to urinary structures occurs when soft tissues are crushed between the pelvic bone (pubic symphysis) and the straddled object.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a bar fight. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation over the left side of the back. An x-ray of the chest shows a fracture of the 12th rib on the left side. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following injuries?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The liver lies in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen deep to the 5th–12th ribs. Right-sided rib fractures are commonly associated with liver injury due to direct transmission of force from the causative blow to the liver and/or penetration of the liver by a fractured segment of a rib. This patient has sustained a left-sided 12th rib fracture, making a liver injury unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

A pneumothorax can develop if there is an inlet of air into the pleural cavity. The posterior attachment of the parietal pleura extends to the 12th rib. The inferior border of the lungs extends only to the 10th rib posteriorly but could be injured and result in a pneumothorax if a fractured segment of the 12th rib penetrates the lung parenchyma during deep inspiration. However, another organ that lies in close proximity to the 12th rib is more likely to be injured.

C) INCORRECT:

The colon is a hollow organ that is elastic and compressible. It is rarely injured in blunt force injuries. Although the splenic flexure of the colon lies in the vicinity of the left 12th rib, they are not in direct contact with one another. Colon perforation due to a fractured segment of a rib is unlikely in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

The kidneys normally lie in a paraspinal, retroperitoneal position that extends from T12–L3. The right kidney is displaced more inferiorly because of the liver. Inferior rib fractures (10–12th ribs) are commonly associated with solid organ injuries to the liver, spleen, and/or kidneys. This patient has sustained a fracture of the posterior aspect of the left 12th rib as is evident from the tenderness over his back and the x-ray findings, which makes a kidney laceration the most likely associated injury.

Left lower rib fractures also commonly cause splenic injury (including splenic rupture) due to the proximity of the posterior surface of the spleen to the left 9th, 10th, and 11th ribs. Splenic injury is more common than kidney injury.
Image Description:

The superior pole of the left kidney is located approximately at T12, while the right kidney is located approximately 3 cm lower due to expansion of the liver.

E) INCORRECT:

The pancreas is a retroperitoneal organ that extends diagonally from the C-loop of the duodenum, anterior to the L2 vertebra (pancreatic head) to the splenic hilum, anterior to the T12 vertebra (pancreatic tail). The pancreas is well-protected from blunt abdominal trauma because it is surrounded by the liver, spleen, stomach, small intestine, left kidney, and the left lower ribs, which diffuse the transmission of force from the causative blow. A forceful blow to the epigastrium (e.g., from falling on the handlebar of a bike) is more likely to injure the body of the pancreas rather than a posterior blow, which this patient has sustained.
Image Description:

The main pancreatic duct and the common bile duct merge and enter the descending part of the duodenum at the major duodenal papilla. The accessory duct enters at the minor duodenal papilla.

Note: individual ductal anatomy may vary
questions.hint: The lower ribs, also known as floating ribs, are not attached to the sternum. Fractured ribs can damage visceral organs.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was a restrained passenger. He reports pelvic pain and involuntary loss of urine, with constant dribbling. Examination shows perineal bruising and there is pain with manual compression of the pelvis. Pelvic ultrasound shows a normal bladder. Injury to which of the following structures is most likely responsible for this patient's urinary incontinence?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Pelvic splanchnic nerves originate from the sacral nerve roots S2–S4 and provide parasympathetic innervation to the rectum, erectile tissue, and detrusor muscle of the bladder. Injury to these nerves (e.g., due to pelvic trauma, as seen in this patient) causes decreased activity of the detrusor muscle, which results in impaired bladder contractility (atonic bladder), overdistention, and decreased sensation of bladder fullness. The resulting overflow incontinence typically manifests with involuntary loss of urine in the form of constant dribbling.

B) INCORRECT:

Genitofemoral nerve injury can occur as a complication of laparoscopic surgery (e.g., hernia repair) or compression (e.g., psoas abscess). Injury to this nerve would cause sensory loss in the scrotal skin and the upper and anterior medial thigh, as well as a decreased cremasteric reflex. Urinary incontinence would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

The superior gluteal nerve innervates the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, which are responsible for abduction of the hip. Injury to this nerve would result in a positive Trendelenburg sign but would not cause urinary incontinence.
Image Description:

The Trendelenburg sign indicates insufficiency of the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles. It is tested for as follows:
(1) The pelvic level is assessed by comparing the height of both iliac crests.
(2) The patient is asked to stand on one leg, with the examiner continuously observing the level of the pelvis and the patient's posture. Normally, the pelvis is stabilized by the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles, which prevent a pelvic drop to the opposite side.
(3) In the case of muscle insufficiency, the pelvis drops towards the unimpaired, unsupported side (free leg), which is known as the Trendelenburg sign.
(4) Tilting of the torso toward the contralateral side compensates for the pelvic drop on the unimpaired side, which is known as Duchenne sign. Because the Duchenne sign may mask the Trendelenburg sign, it is important to always inspect the patient's overall posture.

D) INCORRECT:

Ilioinguinal nerve injury most commonly occurs as a complication of laparoscopic surgery (e.g., hernia repair). Injury to this nerve would cause sensory loss of the upper medial thigh, the root of the penis, and the anterior one-third of the scrotum, as well as a decreased cremasteric reflex. Urinary incontinence would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Obturator nerve injury can also occur with pelvic trauma. Injury to this nerve would cause paralysis of the hip adductors and sensory loss in the medial thigh. Urinary incontinence would not be expected.

F) INCORRECT:

Femoral nerve injury can also occur as a result of pelvic trauma. Injury to this nerve would cause sensory loss in the anteromedial thigh and medial lower leg, as well as motor deficits of the quadriceps, iliacus, pectineus, and sartorius muscles (resulting in impairment in hip flexion, knee extension, and the patellar tendon reflex). Femoral nerve injury does not cause urinary incontinence.
questions.hint: This patient's urinary dribbling is consistent with neurogenic bladder secondary to pelvic trauma. The injured nerve is part of the autonomic nervous system.

questions.text: A 40-year-old sailor is brought to a military treatment facility 20 minutes after being involved in a navy ship collision. He reports a sensation that he needs to urinate but is unable to void. He appears ill. Pulse is 140/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 104/70 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows ecchymoses over the scrotum and perineum. There is tenderness over the suprapubic region and blood at the urethral meatus. Digital rectal examination shows a high-riding prostate. Abdominal ultrasound shows a moderately distended bladder. X-rays of the pelvis show fractures of all four pubic rami. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tearing of the anterior urethra may cause inability to void, blood at the meatus, scrotal and perineal ecchymoses, and perineal tenderness. However, it would not explain this patient's high-riding prostate on physical examination. Furthermore, anterior urethral injuries are more commonly due to straddle injuries, iatrogenic causes (e.g., traumatic catheterization, endoscopy), or penile fractures, but are not associated with pelvic fractures.

B) INCORRECT:

Blunt trauma to the prostate is an unlikely cause of this patient's presentation. High-risk injuries of the pelvis (fractures of all four pubic rami) can lead to tearing of the urethra from the bottom portion of the prostate and could cause inability to void, blood at the meatus, scrotal and perineal ecchymoses, and high-riding prostate on physical examination. However, blunt trauma to the prostate gland itself is not associated with these findings.

C) INCORRECT:

Rupture of the tunica albuginea of the corpus cavernosum is the cause of penile fracture, caused by traumatic bending to an erect penis. Penile fracture may cause penile hematoma or blood at the meatus in the case of concomitant urethral injury. However, penile fracture would not explain this patient's inability to void, scrotal and perineal ecchymoses, or high-riding prostate on physical examination. Also, this type of injury most commonly occurs during sexual intercourse.

D) INCORRECT:

Rupture of the bladder is a complication of high-risk pelvic fractures and may cause urinary retention and suprapubic pain. However, bladder rupture would not explain this patient's blood at the meatus and high-riding prostate on physical examination because of a lack of urethral involvement. Furthermore, patients typically present with gross hematuria, and ultrasound would not show a distended bladder.

E) CORRECT:

Tearing of the posterior urethra causes inability to void despite urge, suprapubic pain, blood at the urethral meatus, scrotal and perineal ecchymoses, and a high-riding prostate, all of which are present in this patient. The membranous portion of the posterior urethra is most susceptible to injury from high-risk pelvic fractures. Therefore, this patient's history of trauma and x-ray findings (fractures of all four pubic rami) are consistent with a torn posterior urethra. This patient should undergo a retrograde cystourethrogram to confirm urethral injury. Generally, placement of a Foley catheter should be avoided prior to performing urethrogram, as it may worsen the injury.

F) INCORRECT:

Tearing of the ureter is a rare complication of pelvic fracture that can cause flank pain, a palpable flank mass (urine and blood), hematuria, and fever, none of which are present in this patient. Ureteral injury would not explain his scrotal and perineal ecchymoses, blood at the meatus, or high-riding prostate on physical examination, which indicates injury to another location of the genitourinary tract.
questions.hint: This patient's high-riding prostate is caused by rupture of the puboprostatic ligament and the collection of blood and urine in the retropubic space.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 45 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. On arrival, he is alert and fully oriented and reports right flank pain. Medical history is remarkable for kidney stones and depression. His only medication is sertraline. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 91/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 132/75 mm Hg. He appears anxious. Physical examination shows multiple superficial abrasions of the extremities. Lungs are clear to auscultation. There is right flank tenderness and tenderness to deep palpation of the right abdomen without guarding or rebound. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count, serum chemistry profile, and coagulation studies, are within normal limits. Urinalysis shows 15 RBC/hpf. CT scan of the abdomen with contrast shows a 1.5-cm laceration of the right kidney with an adjacent, 1.5 x 2-cm hematoma. There is no evidence of urinary extravasation and no free intraperitoneal fluid. Administration of intravenous fluids and analgesics is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A retrograde urethrogram is indicated in all patients with a suspected urethral injury, which commonly develops as a result of trauma and can manifest with hematuria. However, urethral injuries are characterized by presence of blood at the urethral meatus, palpable bladder distension due to an inability to void, and suprapubic pain.

B) INCORRECT:

Exploratory laparotomy should be considered in patients with suspected renal injury following trauma if they are hemodynamically unstable or present with features of active intraabdominal bleeding or injury, such as peritoneal signs. This patient has a small kidney laceration, is hemodynamically stable, and shows no signs of peritoneal irritation. Furthermore, imaging shows no evidence of intraabdominal bleeding.

C) CORRECT:

Conservative management with supportive care and close hemodynamic monitoring is recommended for patients with kidney lacerations who are hemodynamically stable and show no evidence of major renal vascular or urinary collecting system injury. Serial imaging is generally not needed but should be considered if the patient develops signs of deterioration (e.g., worsening flank pain, abdominal distension). Hemodynamically stable patients with vascular or urinary collecting system injuries can also be managed conservatively but should be monitored in the ICU with serial laboratory studies and imaging, as these patients are at increased risk of complications (e.g., bleeding, urinoma). Patients with expanding hematomas but no other signs of active intraabdominal bleeding or injury can be treated with angioembolization. In hemodynamically unstable patients, exploratory laparotomy should be performed.

D) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous nephrostomy may be indicated in a patient with suspected renal pelvic or ureteral injury, both of which can manifest with flank pain and hematuria. However, CT findings of ureteral and renal pelvic injuries include urine extravasation, hydronephrosis, and nonvisualization of the ureter. Moreover, these injuries typically develop in individuals with penetrating or iatrogenic rather than blunt abdominal trauma.

E) INCORRECT:

Ureteral stenting may be indicated in patients with suspected ureteral injury, which can develop as a result of abdominal trauma and manifest with flank pain and hematuria. However, CT findings of ureteral injuries include urine extravasation, hydronephrosis, and nonvisualization of the ureter. Moreover, ureteral injuries typically develop in individuals with penetrating or iatrogenic rather than blunt abdominal trauma.
questions.hint: This patient is hemodynamically stable and his CT scan shows a kidney laceration but no major concomitant injury of the renal vascular or urinary collecting system.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after he was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision where he was the unrestrained passenger. He has severe lower abdominal and pelvic pain. On arrival, he is alert and oriented. His pulse is 95/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 106/62 mm Hg. Examination shows severe tenderness to palpation over the lower abdomen and over the left anterior superior iliac spine. There is no limb length discrepancy. Application of downward pressure over the pelvis shows no springy resistance or instability. Placement of a Foley catheter shows gross hematuria. A focused assessment with sonography (FAST) shows no free fluid in the abdomen. An x-ray of the pelvis shows a stable fracture of the anterior pelvic ring. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous pyelography can be used to assess for renal injury. The most frequent indication for IV pyelography is as a confirmatory test if CT scanning is nondiagnostic. Renal trauma can also manifest with hematuria and should be suspected in patients with associated injuries (e.g., rib fractures) or pain and hematoma over the flank. Because renal trauma is less likely in a patient with lower abdominal pain and a pelvic fracture, evaluation of the lower urinary tract must first be conducted.

B) INCORRECT:

Cystoscopy is indicated for non-emergent cases of unexplained hematuria, but it is not indicated for traumatic hematuria and could further damage the urinary tract.

C) INCORRECT:

External fixation of the pelvis is part of the initial management for unstable pelvic fractures. However, this patient's pelvis was stable on examination and the x-ray showed a stable fracture of the anterior pelvic ring which is unlikely to cause pelvic instability.

D) CORRECT:

Although this patient's FAST shows no free fluid in the abdomen, the presence of hematuria after blunt abdominal trauma is a red flag for GU injury and requires further evaluation. When GU trauma is suspected, the GU tract should be assessed, including the urethra, bladder, ureters, and kidneys. Pelvic fractures in combination with gross hematuria should raise concern for bladder injury. Retrograde cystography (or retrograde CT cystography) is the preferred diagnostic test in patients with suspected bladder rupture. Extravasation of contrast on retrograde cystography confirms the diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal ultrasonography has poor sensitivity for renal trauma and is not indicated for traumatic genitourinary injury. Additionally, in this patient with lower abdominal pain, bladder rupture is a more likely cause of traumatic gross hematuria and therefore requires immediate investigation before assessing the kidneys.
questions.hint: Genitourinary (GU) trauma must always be ruled out in patients with traumatic pelvic fracture, especially when it involves the pubic rami. The presence of lower abdominal pain and gross hematuria further supports a GU trauma.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a bar fight. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation over the left side of the back. An x-ray of the chest shows a fracture of the 12th rib on the left side. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following injuries?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The liver lies in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen deep to the 5th–12th ribs. Right-sided rib fractures are commonly associated with liver injury due to direct transmission of force from the causative blow to the liver and/or penetration of the liver by a fractured segment of a rib. This patient has sustained a left-sided 12th rib fracture, making a liver injury unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

A pneumothorax can develop if there is an inlet of air into the pleural cavity. The posterior attachment of the parietal pleura extends to the 12th rib. The inferior border of the lungs extends only to the 10th rib posteriorly but could be injured and result in a pneumothorax if a fractured segment of the 12th rib penetrates the lung parenchyma during deep inspiration. However, another organ that lies in close proximity to the 12th rib is more likely to be injured.

C) INCORRECT:

The colon is a hollow organ that is elastic and compressible. It is rarely injured in blunt force injuries. Although the splenic flexure of the colon lies in the vicinity of the left 12th rib, they are not in direct contact with one another. Colon perforation due to a fractured segment of a rib is unlikely in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

The kidneys normally lie in a paraspinal, retroperitoneal position that extends from T12–L3. The right kidney is displaced more inferiorly because of the liver. Inferior rib fractures (10–12th ribs) are commonly associated with solid organ injuries to the liver, spleen, and/or kidneys. This patient has sustained a fracture of the posterior aspect of the left 12th rib as is evident from the tenderness over his back and the x-ray findings, which makes a kidney laceration the most likely associated injury.

Left lower rib fractures also commonly cause splenic injury (including splenic rupture) due to the proximity of the posterior surface of the spleen to the left 9th, 10th, and 11th ribs. Splenic injury is more common than kidney injury.
Image Description:

The superior pole of the left kidney is located approximately at T12, while the right kidney is located approximately 3 cm lower due to expansion of the liver.

E) INCORRECT:

The pancreas is a retroperitoneal organ that extends diagonally from the C-loop of the duodenum, anterior to the L2 vertebra (pancreatic head) to the splenic hilum, anterior to the T12 vertebra (pancreatic tail). The pancreas is well-protected from blunt abdominal trauma because it is surrounded by the liver, spleen, stomach, small intestine, left kidney, and the left lower ribs, which diffuse the transmission of force from the causative blow. A forceful blow to the epigastrium (e.g., from falling on the handlebar of a bike) is more likely to injure the body of the pancreas rather than a posterior blow, which this patient has sustained.
Image Description:

The main pancreatic duct and the common bile duct merge and enter the descending part of the duodenum at the major duodenal papilla. The accessory duct enters at the minor duodenal papilla.

Note: individual ductal anatomy may vary
questions.hint: The lower ribs, also known as floating ribs, are not attached to the sternum. Fractured ribs can damage visceral organs.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being struck by a car while he was crossing the street one hour ago. He has pain in his pelvis and an urge to urinate but has been unable to do so since the accident. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/82 mm Hg. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Abdominal examination shows suprapubic tenderness. A scant amount of blood is present at the urethral meatus. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows a fracture of both ipsilateral pubic rami. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Retrograde urethrography is the first step in diagnosing suspected urethral injuries, which often occurs in patients with pelvic fractures due to blunt force trauma (e.g., from motor vehicle collisions). Contrast extravasation from the urethra indicates the precise location of the injury. Foley catheterization should be avoided in patients with suspected urethral injury because it may worsen the condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous pyelography can be used in the evaluation of kidney injuries. This patient does not have features suggesting a kidney injury, such as significant blood loss, hemodynamic instability, ipsilateral pain, or hematoma. Furthermore, in recent years, IV pyelography has been largely replaced by contrast-enhanced CT for diagnosing kidney injuries.

C) INCORRECT:

Retrograde cystography is used to assess for bladder rupture in patients with a pelvic fracture or gross hematuria due to trauma. However, before performing cystography, urethral injury should be ruled out with a different diagnostic approach.

D) INCORRECT:

Foley catheterization is commonly used in patients with urinary retention. However, urethral catheterization should be avoided in suspected urethral injury as it may worsen the condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Retroperitoneal ultrasound can be used to evaluate retroperitoneal structures, including the kidneys. However, this patient does not have signs of a kidney injury, such as significant blood loss, hemodynamic instability, ipsilateral pain, or hematoma.
questions.hint: Blood at the urethral meatus and features of urinary retention (inability to void, suprapubic pain) in the setting of a pelvic fracture suggest urethral injury.

questions.text: A 40-year-old sailor is brought to a military treatment facility 20 minutes after being involved in a navy ship collision. He reports a sensation that he needs to urinate but is unable to void. Pulse is 140/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 104/70 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows ecchymoses over the scrotum and perineum. There is tenderness over the suprapubic region and blood at the urethral meatus. Digital rectal examination shows a high-riding prostate. Abdominal ultrasound shows a moderately distended bladder. X-rays of the pelvis show fractures of all four pubic rami. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Blunt trauma to the prostate is an unlikely cause of this patient's presentation. High-risk injuries of the pelvis (fractures of all four pubic rami) can lead to tearing of the urethra from the bottom portion of the prostate and could cause inability to void, blood at the meatus, scrotal and perineal ecchymoses, and high-riding prostate on physical examination. However, blunt trauma to the prostate gland itself is not associated with these findings.

B) INCORRECT:

Rupture of the tunica albuginea of the corpus cavernosum is the cause of penile fracture, caused by traumatic bending to an erect penis. Penile fracture may cause penile hematoma or blood at the meatus in the case of concomitant urethral injury. However, penile fracture would not explain this patient's inability to void, scrotal and perineal ecchymoses, or high-riding prostate on physical examination. Also, this type of injury most commonly occurs during sexual intercourse.

C) INCORRECT:

Rupture of the bladder is a complication of high-risk pelvic fractures and may cause urinary retention and suprapubic pain. However, bladder rupture would not explain this patient's blood at the meatus and high-riding prostate on physical examination because of a lack of urethral involvement. Furthermore, patients typically present with gross hematuria, and ultrasound would not show a distended bladder.

D) CORRECT:

Tearing of the posterior urethra causes inability to void despite urge, suprapubic pain, blood at the urethral meatus, scrotal and perineal ecchymoses, and a high-riding prostate, all of which are present in this patient. The membranous portion of the posterior urethra is most susceptible to injury from high-risk pelvic fractures. Therefore, this patient's history of trauma and x-ray findings (fractures of all four pubic rami) are consistent with a torn posterior urethra. This patient should undergo a retrograde cystourethrogram to confirm urethral injury. Generally, placement of a Foley catheter should be avoided prior to performing urethrogram, as it may worsen the injury.

E) INCORRECT:

Tearing of the ureter is a rare complication of pelvic fracture that can cause flank pain, a palpable flank mass (urine and blood), hematuria, and fever, none of which are present in this patient. Ureteral injury would not explain his scrotal and perineal ecchymoses, blood at the meatus, or high-riding prostate on physical examination, which indicates injury to another location of the genitourinary tract.
questions.hint: This patient's high-riding prostate is caused by the collection of blood and urine in the retropubic space.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after losing control of his bicycle and colliding with a parked car. He was thrown over the handlebars and hit the ground. He has mild pain in his legs and on his right side but says that he feels well otherwise. His pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/76 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is tenderness to palpation over the right thorax. There is no pelvic instability. A voided urine specimen is clear. Microscopic examination of the urine shows 85 RBCs/hpf. A focused assessment with sonography for trauma shows no free intraabdominal fluid. An x-ray of the chest shows a fracture of the 11th rib on the right side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous pyelography (IVP) is used for the evaluation of possible renal disease, detection of renal stones, or to assess potential contrast extravasation if contrast-enhanced CT images are not diagnostic. IVP was formerly a preferred imaging modality for renal trauma; however, a different test has supplanted IVP as the imaging modality of choice.

B) INCORRECT:

Exploratory laparotomy after BAT is indicated in hemodynamically unstable patients with signs of peritonitis and hemodynamically stable patients with evidence of free intraabdominal fluid on imaging. This patient is hemodynamically stable and focused assessment with sonography for trauma is normal.

C) CORRECT:

In patients with BAT, a CT scan with contrast of the abdomen and pelvis is the imaging modality of choice for evaluating abdominal injuries, including those of the genitourinary tract. BAT is a major cause of mortality and requires a high degree of clinical suspicion, even if a patient's initial presentation does not suggest any significant intraabdominal injury. This patient with suspected renal trauma requires a CT scan with contrast of the abdomen and pelvis to establish the diagnosis and further assess the degree of trauma.

D) INCORRECT:

Retrograde urethrocystography is used to evaluate the lower genitourinary tract and urinary bladder. It is indicated in patients with gross hematuria or blood at the urethral meatus following a pelvic fracture. This patient, however, only has microscopic hematuria and no signs of a pelvic fracture. Therefore, a retrograde urethrocystography is not indicated at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Observation and follow-up may be appropriate in patients who are hemodynamically stable and have no signs of traumatic injury. Although mild microscopic hematuria is common following BAT and does not necessarily indicate genitourinary injury, this patient has evidence of a right rib fracture, which is concerning for a renal injury. Therefore, observation and follow-up would not be an appropriate next step.
questions.hint: The combination of a fracture of the 11th rib on the right side and microscopic hematuria in a patient with a history of blunt abdominal trauma (BAT) should raise concern for renal injury.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up examination. Four months ago, he was treated conservatively for ureteric colic. He has noticed during micturition that his urine is reddish-brown initially and then clears by the end of the stream. He has no dysuria. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 122/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Urine studies show:


Blood
2+


Protein
negative


Leukocyte esterase
negative


Nitrite
negative


RBCs
5–7/hpf


WBCs
0–1/hpf


RBC casts
none


Which of the following is the most likely origin of this patient's hematuria?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glomerular damage can manifest with gross hematuria. However, urine (and blood) from the kidneys collects in the bladder before urination, which causes the full volume of urine to be discolored by blood (total hematuria). Additionally, urine studies would show RBC casts and/or dysmorphic RBCs (due to erythrocyte packing within the nephron), as well as proteinuria in many cases.

B) INCORRECT:

Ureteric lesions (e.g., due to nephrolithiasis, malignancy, or infection) can manifest with hematuria. Urine (and blood) from the ureters collects in the bladder before urination, which causes the full volume of urine to be discolored by blood (total hematuria). This patient's urine is only bloody initially, then clears, which suggests another source of bleeding.

C) INCORRECT:

Hematuria from the renal pelvis can be caused by a variety of processes, including pyelonephritis, malignancy, or nephrolithiasis. However, urine (and blood) from the renal pelvis collects in the bladder before urination, causing the full volume of urine to be discolored by blood (total hematuria). While this patient has a history of nephrolithiasis, his urine is only bloody initially, suggesting another source of bleeding.

D) CORRECT:

Initial hematuria is suggestive of urethral bleeding. Blood from the urethra (or prostate) is voided first, then washed out by non-bloody urine from the bladder. For this reason, gross hematuria of urethral origin is only observed at the beginning of micturition.

Hematuria of urethral origin can have a wide variety of causes, such as infection (urethritis, prostatitis), neoplasm (urothelial carcinoma, urethral papilloma, BPH), anatomical variations (urethral stricture), and trauma (e.g., insertion of a Foley catheter, passage of a kidney stone). Patients with painless hematuria, particularly those > 35 years of age such as this patient, should always be thoroughly evaluated to rule out malignancy.

E) INCORRECT:

Bleeding from the bladder is either associated with hematuria that continues for the duration of micturition, or terminal hematuria, which suggests a lesion at the trigone.
questions.hint: The bladder stores urine (and sometimes blood) from the upper genitourinary tract, where the contents mix for extended periods of time.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department following a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He complains of severe pelvic pain and has not voided since the injury. Examination reveals blood at the urethral meatus, a boggy prostate on gentle palpation, and a swollen, bruised scrotum. Pelvic radiographs show multiple fractures of the pubic rami. Preliminary attempts to pass a Foley catheter were met with significant resistance (see report).


Heart rate
95/min


Blood pressure
120/80 mmHg


Retrograde urethrogram: Complete disruption of the posterior urethra
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging of the pelvis
Immediate primary surgical repair of the urethra

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance imaging provides detailed soft tissue evaluation but is impractical in acute trauma settings. The clinical findings and retrograde urethrogram already confirm complete posterior urethral disruption, directing management toward immediate urinary diversion rather than further imaging.

B) INCORRECT:

Immediate primary repair of urethral injuries in the context of pelvic fractures and complete posterior urethral disruption is challenging due to extensive soft tissue damage and edema. Attempting repair in such conditions can lead to complications like stricture formation and incontinence. A staged approach with initial urinary diversion is preferred to allow inflammation resolution and precise reconstruction later.

C) INCORRECT:

Complete posterior urethral disruption, indicated by blood at the urethral meatus and a boggy prostate, contraindicates further transurethral catheter attempts. Resistance during initial catheterization and imaging findings suggest that repeated attempts risk creating a false passage, increasing bleeding and infection risk.

D) CORRECT:

In cases of complete posterior urethral disruption, especially with pelvic fractures, urinary diversion is crucial. Blood at the urethral meatus, inability to void, and a boggy prostate suggest significant urethral injury, confirmed by retrograde urethrogram. Transurethral catheterization risks exacerbating the injury. Suprapubic cystostomy decompresses the bladder, minimizes further urethral damage, and reduces infection risk, allowing for delayed urethral reconstruction when inflammation subsides.

Key learning point: In cases of urethral injury with pelvic fracture, suprapubic cystostomy is the appropriate next step to avoid further urethral trauma and allow for urinary diversion.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department after a high-speed motorcycle crash. He complains of severe pelvic pain. He is hemodynamically stable. Examination reveals a pelvic fracture, blood at the urethral meatus, and a tender, distended bladder. Digital rectal examination shows a non-palpable prostate. A gentle attempt at Foley catheterization meets resistance. He has not voided since the accident (see report).
Retrograde urethrogram: Complete posterior urethral disruption
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Immediate open surgical repair under general anesthesia
Begin intravenous antibiotics and await spontaneous healing

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In the context of pelvic fracture with blood at the urethral meatus and a distended bladder, there is a high suspicion for urethral injury. The retrograde urethrogram confirms a complete posterior urethral disruption. Attempting further urethral instrumentation can exacerbate the injury. A suprapubic catheter provides urinary drainage by bypassing the injured urethra, minimizing additional trauma. This approach allows for stabilization and prepares the patient for delayed definitive repair once inflammation subsides.

Key learning point: In cases of urethral injury due to pelvic fracture, a suprapubic catheter is the appropriate first step to ensure urinary drainage while avoiding further urethral damage.

B) INCORRECT:

Immediate open surgical repair in the acute trauma setting is not recommended due to significant edema and inflammation, which complicate the procedure and increase the risk of complications. Initial management focuses on urinary diversion with a suprapubic catheter, allowing for stabilization and planning for later definitive repair.

C) INCORRECT:

Repeating transurethral catheterization under sedation does not address the mechanical discontinuity of a complete posterior urethral disruption. The resistance encountered during initial catheterization and the retrograde urethrogram findings indicate that further attempts could worsen the injury or create false passages.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous antibiotics do not address the urinary obstruction caused by complete posterior urethral disruption. Without effective urinary drainage, complications such as urinoma formation and fibrosis can occur. Spontaneous healing is unlikely, necessitating immediate urinary diversion with a suprapubic catheter.

On examination, he has tenderness to palpation over the left side of his back. A chest x-ray reveals a fracture of the 12th rib on the left side. Further evaluation is most likely to show which one of the following injuries?

A 43-year-old man comes to your clinic for follow-up. Four months ago, he was treated conservatively for ureteric colic.
